componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Schwartz with Raymond James.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple on the DOL. First, could you discuss maybe affiliated distribution, how their payments might change under the final rule than what currently exists?
componenttext: A couple on the DOL. First, could you discuss maybe affiliated distribution, how their payments might change under the final rule than what currently exists?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, be happy to do that. And I got to tell you, Steven, I just want to make a couple more comments on DOL more broadly just to set the tone in addition to my earlier prepared comments. We just can't, as a country, lose the fact that we've amassed $15 tri
componenttext: Yes, be happy to do that. And I got to tell you, Steven, I just want to make a couple more comments on DOL more broadly just to set the tone in addition to my earlier prepared comments. We just can't, as a country, lose the fact that we've amassed $15 trillion in rollover IRAs, 401(k)s, another $7 trillion in Defined Benefit. There's $22 trillion in this country, which arguably, would make it the most successful retirement system anywhere in the world. Secondly, the DOL, I believe their intentions are good. I think about the intent of the laws is to protect the interest of the U.S. retirement savers, it's about creating transparency around cost and benefits and value. It's also about making sure we have access to the competitive marketplace. There are some unintended consequences, and that's what Dan will respond to in just a minute relative to working with advisers. There's a view that the Robo solutions don’t solve problems for small account balance holders. That's just not the case, and so we have some more work to do there. The second is we want to make sure that we're not creating barriers or reduce the number of advisers that have in the past and will in the future, provide important education to individuals and to savers. And then we also want to make sure that we don't limit the number of individualized solutions that we can present to plan participants. They're very dependent on that enroller, if you will. So with that as a backdrop, I'll ask Deanna to weigh in on the implications on principal adviser network and how we might have to do things slightly differently.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks. Just a couple of comments. And first of all, I want to put into kind of context the impact on our affiliated distribution. And so first, I think it's important to point out that our advisers sell in service across an entire range of product o
componenttext: Yes, thanks. Just a couple of comments. And first of all, I want to put into kind of context the impact on our affiliated distribution. And so first, I think it's important to point out that our advisers sell in service across an entire range of product offerings, including many products within Principle that are not impacted by the DOL regulation. In fact, the majority of that systems revenue comes from transaction that are not impacted by the proposal. Having said that, I think there's a couple of points that I think is important to keep in mind as we think about even those products that do fall under the regulation. First of all, as Dan mentioned in his opening remarks, the final regs did allow for a pass forward on proprietary products, and that applies to both funds within our retirement plan as well as retail products sold at the time of either retirement or when participants change jobs. I think the other thing to keep in mind is our affiliated advisers already today have a choice. We have both proprietary and non-proprietary products and solutions. And our proprietary offerings will have to continue to compete on items such as investment performance and service as they do today. So we will have some business model changes for that channel, that will come in the realm of compensation changes, like you mentioned, compliance. But I think we're very confident that our business model can adjust, and feel good about our ability to comply as well as continue to stay focused on meeting the needs of those customers that we serve.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Deanna, if I remember correctly, the affiliated distribution does get paid more proprietary. My understanding is that you could still do proprietary, but if you're going to use the [indiscernible] of that, that has to go away? Is that right?
componenttext: Okay, Deanna, if I remember correctly, the affiliated distribution does get paid more proprietary. My understanding is that you could still do proprietary, but if you're going to use the [indiscernible] of that, that has to go away? Is that right?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and those are things that we're looking at. And some of the places we already have some fee -- some comp leveling already in place, in other places, we will have to adjust. But I think it comes back to, our advisers already tried to do what's in the
componenttext: Yes, and those are things that we're looking at. And some of the places we already have some fee -- some comp leveling already in place, in other places, we will have to adjust. But I think it comes back to, our advisers already tried to do what's in the best interest of those clients. And ultimately, we have great investment performance, we have great product features and good solutions that we continue to feel that we'll have the ability to service our customers. And so both our products and the nonproprietary products within the platform going forward.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A [indiscernible] has been in place, Steven, for a long time. This is Dan, levelized missions been in place for a long time. And I think it's only on the margin that we've had any additional sort of compensation. And that's going to be rationalized across
componenttext: A [indiscernible] has been in place, Steven, for a long time. This is Dan, levelized missions been in place for a long time. And I think it's only on the margin that we've had any additional sort of compensation. And that's going to be rationalized across the entire industry. And so again, I don't see that as an impediment to the Principle adviser network to continue going about that they do today are to take care of the customers and the participants.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on the independent side of distribution. Do you have distribution in which you will be considered the financial institution?
componenttext: Okay. And on the independent side of distribution. Do you have distribution in which you will be considered the financial institution?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that is on a very limited basis. And the way I would describe that is already within our call centers, we are providing information, we're providing some education, and we're not dispensing advice. Our wholesalers work with independent third-party
componenttext: I think that is on a very limited basis. And the way I would describe that is already within our call centers, we are providing information, we're providing some education, and we're not dispensing advice. Our wholesalers work with independent third-party administrators. They work with wirehouses, and all of our alliance partners to distribute our products. We don't sell these plans on a direct basis. It's the adviser who would be acting in the capacity of the fiduciary in order to help them pick and choose the investments and these plans. So the only -- go ahead.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Dan, that's what I'm asking. What I'm asking is you have a situation over in West Desmoines here where the insurance companies deal with independent agents and would be considered a financial institution under the beck. And the question is, how can
componenttext: Well, Dan, that's what I'm asking. What I'm asking is you have a situation over in West Desmoines here where the insurance companies deal with independent agents and would be considered a financial institution under the beck. And the question is, how can they be the financial institution have the liability and still be able to manage independent people who are going to do what they're going to do?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question. Nora is going to weigh in here and provide some additional color for you on that specific question.
componenttext: Yes, good question. Nora is going to weigh in here and provide some additional color for you on that specific question.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's not -- Steven, that's not our model. They've got a different model than we have. And if you're talking about the retirement business that Dan was addressing, our model, as Dan said, is we are going to -- we'll have a wholesaler who's working w
componenttext: Yes, that's not -- Steven, that's not our model. They've got a different model than we have. And if you're talking about the retirement business that Dan was addressing, our model, as Dan said, is we are going to -- we'll have a wholesaler who's working with that independent adviser. But to that point, that independent adviser and their firm would take on the obligations under the new DOL rule.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from the line of Sean Dargan with Macquarie.
componenttext: You're next question comes from the line of Sean Dargan with Macquarie.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, Dan, is there are any update on board's thoughts of the CFO search?
componenttext: I was wondering, Dan, is there are any update on board's thoughts of the CFO search?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Sean, thanks for the question this morning. Terry is a tough guy to replace, we all know that, and we have a search going on for both internal and external candidates. There's what I consider to be a really good pool of candidates out there. We'll h
componenttext: Sure. Sean, thanks for the question this morning. Terry is a tough guy to replace, we all know that, and we have a search going on for both internal and external candidates. There's what I consider to be a really good pool of candidates out there. We'll have a board meeting later in May, which I'll provide an update to the board on progress that we're making towards that end. Terry is committed to staying on board as long as it takes in order to get the new person appropriately aligned and onboard here at Principal. So again, we feel very good about where we're at today in that search process.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Terry. Thanks for the question. I appreciate it.
componenttext: This is Terry. Thanks for the question. I appreciate it.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're a hard man to replace, Terry. Given the $400 million authorization you've got during the quarter and where your shares are trading, I'm just wondering why -- or if you can share with us your thoughts on why you didn't put the, I guess, the pedal to
componenttext: You're a hard man to replace, Terry. Given the $400 million authorization you've got during the quarter and where your shares are trading, I'm just wondering why -- or if you can share with us your thoughts on why you didn't put the, I guess, the pedal to the floor and buy more stock when the it was down at those levels.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first thing I would say is you never know what levels the stocks are ever going to trade at. And so again, we're very displayed on how we go about executing on share repurchase. Remember that we had an older share authorization that had been in place
componenttext: The first thing I would say is you never know what levels the stocks are ever going to trade at. And so again, we're very displayed on how we go about executing on share repurchase. Remember that we had an older share authorization that had been in place which we completed. And so that was roughly $86 million...

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: $75 million. And so good progress was made in closing out the previous authorization. We still have a lot of dry powder from here, but with that, I'll throw over to Terry to add some additional color.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sean, as we looked at and as we've had looked at capital deployment, we always look at it in terms of a very balanced long-term view. We're looking for that what will enhance the shareholder's value. No buying back shares is one of the options. But w
componenttext: Yes, Sean, as we looked at and as we've had looked at capital deployment, we always look at it in terms of a very balanced long-term view. We're looking for that what will enhance the shareholder's value. No buying back shares is one of the options. But we look at all kinds of different things in terms of -- to enhance shareholder value as well as to distribute that value as it's created. If you look at over the last several years, you'd see we've done a pretty good job of balancing it between our organic growth and acquisitions in order to create shareholder value and then increasing our dividend payout ratio as we just increased the dividend again, as we marched towards that 40% of net income. And buyback is just another part of the program here. And so we talked about, in 2016, $800 million to $1 billion. And we're on track to do that. And we think that as you mentioned though, that the share buyback program is a very important part of that so far. So to the first quarter, we have $86 million. As of yesterday, we added another $26 million in the program. So we're over $100 million now. We're looking at it over a long term, we do have a program that gets accelerated as the share price goes lower. Hopefully, we don’t have to worry about that in the near future. But as we look into the second half of the year, we've got options. We've got opportunities to continue to pay out our dividend and increase it towards that 40% payout ratio. We're also looking at acquisition activity for the remainder of the year. And as we've talked about in the past, we looked at increasing our share of some PGI boutiques, and so we'll look at that as well. We'll also think about the share buyback. So as I've mentioned, we've continued to build that out. So we got over $360 [ph] million yet in our authorization. So that is a very integral part of the share buyback -- excuse me, of the capital deployment strategy this environment. And then we'll also continue to look at opportunities to capital structure and reduce our debt and reduce our debt leverage because we do have some high coupon debt out there that we could -- if the opportunity presents itself, use that for that. So we're going to continue very balanced, disciplined, long-term approach to our capital deployment strategy. And I think we're well on our way to distributing that $800 million to $1 billion. Hope that helps.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Suneet Kamath with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Suneet Kamath with UBS.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to go to the FSA business. You talked about hitting the 1% to 3% beginning of period in terms of sales or flows. I think in that commentary, there was some talk about balancing growth and discipline. So can you just give some color on what you
componenttext: Just wanted to go to the FSA business. You talked about hitting the 1% to 3% beginning of period in terms of sales or flows. I think in that commentary, there was some talk about balancing growth and discipline. So can you just give some color on what you're seeing in the pricing market in the 401(k) business?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question. I'll make some comments and throw it over to Nora. Clearly, there's a lot of questions being asked today in the qualified retirement planning market with all the deal well overhang. That's starting to consume, I think, a lot of pe
componenttext: Thanks for the question. I'll make some comments and throw it over to Nora. Clearly, there's a lot of questions being asked today in the qualified retirement planning market with all the deal well overhang. That's starting to consume, I think, a lot of people's time as they advise their clients on what's transpiring because this has hit mainstream media in terms of the issues. We did an outstanding job in the current quarter retaining clients. We did a nice job acquiring clients. Our strong investment performance certainly helps contribute to that -- to that success. Having said that, the net cash flow was healthy for us, but these are things that are a little bit lumpy, and I'll have Nora kind of weigh in now and talk about some of that lumpiness and her views broadly on the FSA line.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. We certainly believe we're striking the right balance, and we think we have the proof points for it. With the kind of plan retention we're seeing, with the kind of the sales we're seeing, we're always looking -- obviously we've got a compet
componenttext: Good question. We certainly believe we're striking the right balance, and we think we have the proof points for it. With the kind of plan retention we're seeing, with the kind of the sales we're seeing, we're always looking -- obviously we've got a competitive market we're dealing in. But one of the things that we're seeing is, in particular, in that small to medium, that core segment of our market, we're seeing just a tremendous opportunity for us as we move in that space. And what we've seen is as we look at that growth in our -- both in our sales and retention, that, that's the piece of it that is really outperforming for us. The lumpiness that we talked about, the volatility we talked about comes when 1 or 2 larger cases. So you think in terms of $500 million or north of $500 million. Now oftentimes, when we talk about the discipline between growth and profitability, it's with those larger cases in making a decision that we're not willing to race to the bottom on pricing. So that's the kind of lumpiness you'll see, and that's why we'll have quarters like we had this quarter with the $3 billion really outstanding net cash flow, but we don't want to get over our skis and extrapolating that because we will have 1 or 2 large plan decisions over the year that will move that number, which is why we continue to reaffirm the guidance that if we look at a full year rather than a quarter-to-quarter, if we look at the full year, we're confident given what we see today that we're going to be well within that 1% to 3% of beginning of the year account value. But the caveat that we always throw out is because our core business is small and medium businesses, when you have 1 or 2 of those larger cases moving in or out, that can swing the numbers, which is why we tend to look full year rather than quarter-to-quarter.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. Just to come back at the large account side. Can you just give us some quantum in terms of how much pricing has changed, maybe year-over-year, in that large market acknowledging that, that kind of opportunistic for you?
componenttext: That makes sense. Just to come back at the large account side. Can you just give us some quantum in terms of how much pricing has changed, maybe year-over-year, in that large market acknowledging that, that kind of opportunistic for you?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's -- there hasn't been in -- from what we see, it's not a year-over-year comparison. That large case market has been extremely competitive for many, many years. And where we compete in that large case market is: One, investment performance, and Da
componenttext: Yes, it's -- there hasn't been in -- from what we see, it's not a year-over-year comparison. That large case market has been extremely competitive for many, many years. And where we compete in that large case market is: One, investment performance, and Dan and Jim have talked about that, especially in that key asset classes target date. We have a tremendous amount of choice there. We got extremely strong investment performance. So we compete in that space very well with regard to that suite of [indiscernible] classes. In addition, on service side, because our scale, we're able to move up and down, whether it's a small business, a medium business or a large business, we scale our service platform to the point where that is seamless for us. So we compete very well in that space, both an the investment side and the service side. But again, we're going to always be disciplined around this growth and profitability access.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Dan. Just a couple of comments. The TRS, the total retirement suite, still is a very, very powerful tool for the Principal that can differentiate value from pure 401(k) players. So that again, as a differentiator, frozen Defined Benefit, deferred
componenttext: This is Dan. Just a couple of comments. The TRS, the total retirement suite, still is a very, very powerful tool for the Principal that can differentiate value from pure 401(k) players. So that again, as a differentiator, frozen Defined Benefit, deferred compensations, ESOP had a nice quarter here. So that is a nice differentiator. The other point I'd make is, because this generalization of large case pricing. There are so many components that go into the pricing of a large plan. How many payroll centers? What is the current penetration rate relative to participant involvement? What's the customized communications packages? All of those variables go into that. So when we lose a plan or win a plan, it's because we've done the homework behind the scenes to understand exactly what kind of resources are going to have to be deployed against that plan. So that's why at any given time, you could lose a plan or win a plan. But again, we like the model that we have. We think it resonates in the marketplace, and our retention rate would imply that those large plans appreciate it. Hopefully that helps.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it definitely does. One last quick one, or maybe not so quick. As we think about the DOL, I think we all know there's been some deep pressure in the 401(k) business just for years. But do we think, or should we think that the DOL rule could accelerate
componenttext: No, it definitely does. One last quick one, or maybe not so quick. As we think about the DOL, I think we all know there's been some deep pressure in the 401(k) business just for years. But do we think, or should we think that the DOL rule could accelerate some of that pressure?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don’t -- well, I think as you pointed out very appropriately. And frankly, it's not limited to just this industry, it's all industries where there's constant pressure. It's one of the advantages for being a leader in industry, having critical mass and
componenttext: I don’t -- well, I think as you pointed out very appropriately. And frankly, it's not limited to just this industry, it's all industries where there's constant pressure. It's one of the advantages for being a leader in industry, having critical mass and scale and capability and having great partners out there. I would not anticipate there to be any pressure coming off fee structures because of DOL. Could it cause some additional discussion? It should because it's really around transparency and making sure the people understand what they're paying and what they're getting for their money. So again, I think on a marginal basis, I think we'll continue to have a lot of dialogue around cost and pricing, and Nora wanted to make one more comment here.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Suneet, I think the one phenomenon that we expect is that when you look at the complexity of this reg, when you look at compliance cost, you really need to be a player that's at scale, and you need to be a player that can come to the market, not just
componenttext: Yes, Suneet, I think the one phenomenon that we expect is that when you look at the complexity of this reg, when you look at compliance cost, you really need to be a player that's at scale, and you need to be a player that can come to the market, not just at scale but with the kind of expertise to deal with this fiduciary duty. And when you think about that, the logical conclusion is you're going to have sub-scaled players or folks that don't have this as their core business, having a moment in time here where there may be moving out of the market. So we see it as an opportunity around consolidation. And I think that goes back to your question about pricing. I think the irony here is that those of us who are at scale that have the expertise are going to stay in the market. And I think there will be a number of players who will take this as their opportunity to exit the market.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Dan, one maybe bigger picture question as it relates to the DOL. Do you think it has any impact on the pace of the rollover market?
componenttext: I guess, Dan, one maybe bigger picture question as it relates to the DOL. Do you think it has any impact on the pace of the rollover market?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. I think what it's going to cause is at the inflection point of a job changer or a retiree, they're going to call into a call center like they always have, because that's the typical sort of process. And they're going to be having a conversa
componenttext: Good question. I think what it's going to cause is at the inflection point of a job changer or a retiree, they're going to call into a call center like they always have, because that's the typical sort of process. And they're going to be having a conversation with a person providing education and guidance. And they're going to disclose what the pricing is in the current plan structure, in a qualified retirement plan. It could be larger plan. And there's going to be a certain price. And they're also, as they always have in the past, disclosed to them that there are other options for them to consider. They could move that money to a rollover IRA with a Principal, or they could roll over that money to a third-party. And the names are common. You would know all of those. And the burden that now falls on the adviser is that the participant has a very clear understanding that they're moving from one product to another. And they have to look at it on a couple of different dimensions. One dimension, of course, is the investment lineup. Is it the same, or is it different? Another dimension is what's the underlying performance of those investment options? The third dimension is on the price. What am I paying and what am I getting in exchange for that? And it doesn't have to be the same price, but there has to be a thorough understanding and explanation on why there is a difference for the price being paid. That action onto itself is going to take a longer conversation for fully betting that opportunity. It ties it back to my earlier statements that small account balance holders could find that there are fewer advisers willing to invest the time and the energy to vet every one of those situations. So I think there is a likelihood that 401(k) service providers could end up almost, by default, retaining maybe more of those smaller account balances after they've had that discussion with that phone counselor. I think on the larger account balances, there are advisers that are going to be spending the time to help get the opportunity. And the last comment I would make is, remember that we are a significant player in the rollover business for Defined Contribution Investment Only, where Jim Coggins PGI investment products not only find themselves on the platform of many 401(k) chassis but also they find themselves on rollover IRA chassis, and again, with strong performance and investment options and sold needs for long-term savers, I think that's a net plus. So I hope it's not too long winded of an answer, John. Do you have a follow-up?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's very helpful. I do have a follow-up, just on a separate topic. I appreciate for sure that Principal International continues to generate positive net flows now for 30 straight quarters. But in the last several quarters, those net flows have cert
componenttext: No, that's very helpful. I do have a follow-up, just on a separate topic. I appreciate for sure that Principal International continues to generate positive net flows now for 30 straight quarters. But in the last several quarters, those net flows have certainly declined. And I'm just curious, as you think about the outlook and some of the economic issues, particularly in the few of the Latin American countries, whether you think there's a chance that we can see that string of positive net flows actually come to an end here soon?

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, again, I'll have Luis clean this up. We're benefited because we operate, not only in Latin America, but we also operate in Asia, and we're leveraging much of what Tim or Jim brings relative to institutional asset management to those PI countries. I'm
componenttext: Yes, again, I'll have Luis clean this up. We're benefited because we operate, not only in Latin America, but we also operate in Asia, and we're leveraging much of what Tim or Jim brings relative to institutional asset management to those PI countries. I'm also encouraged by some of the recovery that's happening in some of the countries, like Brazil, where you see their equity markets in the first quarter recovering by almost 12%. And they're up 15%, and the currency has recovered by approximately 12%. So I think there's some signs that these emerging countries are going through the process. Although they still show negative GDP in some cases, there are some signs that the new capital being countries and things are bouncing back. But to your specific question on net capitals, I'll defer to Luis to answer that.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is a very good question. Let me tell you what is our view of our business. It seemed to me that we're able to saw that rock bottom -- solid rock bottom cycle of the emerging market, very much more around January. If you're looking to equity FX,
componenttext: John, this is a very good question. Let me tell you what is our view of our business. It seemed to me that we're able to saw that rock bottom -- solid rock bottom cycle of the emerging market, very much more around January. If you're looking to equity FX, confidence indexes and commodity prices, even interest rates are showing a much better picture for emerging markets today. Oil prices above $46, $48 today, copper prices in 2 28. FX going in the right direction. So what happened with our net customer cash flow, you could see our financial supplement, trailing 12 months, we are [indiscernible] in at $9.3 billion in trailing 12 months. We put in $900 million net customer cash flow in the first quarter. If you're looking the plan that we have had during 2015, first quarter, second quarter, third quarter, fourth quarter, in the first part of the year, average per quarter $2.5 billion, $3 billion in net customer cash flows, average in the second part of the year, $1.5 billion, $1.8 billion, and then we had $1 billion. But if you're going into the first quarter, I would say that January, February, March, they had a very positive,  I would say, behavior. February was a pretty much more flat, better February and much better March. So I would say that the $900 million that we do have in first quarter is not an indication of what is our real run rate that we are looking forward during 2016.

componenttext: Okay. So I mean and I get that some of these markets have rebounded, some of the commodity data points and a few other data points have certainly improved. And so I would absolutely expect that we see investment performance pick up. I was more concerned about GDP and employment levels as it relates to some of the net flows, but it sounds like you expect improvement there, too.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: That is correct, John. We have a -- and again, we have a much better kind of idea about what is going to happen. And certainly, if you're looking even in employment levels, even in a country like Brazil, certainly the unemployment is kind of going a little bit up that Brazil, in particular, continues to be very solid. The net customer cash flows out of Brazil was $1 billion in the first quarter. And the trailing 12 months, it's at $6 billion. And we certainly, for a second quarter, the same. We have a better, much better idea about those net customer catch flows are going to be, very much more aligned about what has been our run rate in the past.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, one thing -- comfort about the net cash flows in emerging markets is they are still that. In the U.S., some of this negative cash flow pressure points from paying out benefits, It's why we're in the business. And if you look at Latin America and Asi
componenttext: John, one thing -- comfort about the net cash flows in emerging markets is they are still that. In the U.S., some of this negative cash flow pressure points from paying out benefits, It's why we're in the business. And if you look at Latin America and Asia, they just don't have the same level of payout the current use it relates to generating retirement income. So we've got lot of emerging markets with a lot of upside for middle-class growth in accumulation phase here in the next decade or so.

headline: Principal Financial Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Mike, this is a pretty interesting question as well. I mean net customer cash flows, as you could see in our supplement, we are reporting $17 billion just for China in the first quarter, trailing 12 months about $20 billion. So there has been a very impressive performance. I would say that we think that China is going to be very much more -- I mean -- it's past, and it's going to be very much more in line about what you can see in our trailing 12-month expectations rather than what really happened in the first quarter of 2016. Having said that, we have been very focused on certain things like asset retention above the word that we're pulling ahead. And the things that is important to keep in mind is that our joint venture has been perceived as a Safe Harbor in China. And also, we haven been perceived as a much more conservative asset manager in mutual fund company. So we have been benefit for the kind of noise in China. But certainly, we think that our run rate is going to be very much more in line above the numbers that you could see in the trailing 12 months, rather than what really happened in the very last quarter in China.
